etymologies: late 16th century; earliest use found in Angell Day (fl. 1563–1595), stationer and writer. Either from post-classical Latin remuneratorius affording remuneration, or from remunerate + -ory, perhaps partly after Middle French remuneratoire

definitions: That provides or is concerned with remuneration or reward; affording or given in remuneration; remunerative.
